keyTakeAways: A daylight robbery at the Louvre Museum in Paris saw four masked thieves steal high-value jewellery in less than eight minutes.
The stolen items include a diamond and emerald necklace from Emperor Napoleon, a tiara worn by Empress Eugenie, and pieces previously owned by Queen Marie-Amelie.
Experts believe the stolen jewellery has likely been melted down into precious metals and smuggled out of the country, as the items were not destroyed but rather repurposed for profit.
Investigators found a damaged crown belonging to Empress Eugenie on the thieves' escape route, indicating the heist was executed with speed and precision.
Security flaws were identified, including one in three rooms lacking CCTV and failure of the main alarm system to activate.
French President Emmanuel Macron described the robbery as an attack on France's cultural heritage.
Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin criticized security failures, stating that the thieves' ability to drive a modified truck to the museum damaged France's image.
The estimated value of the stolen jewellery is €88 million (approximately £76 million or $102 million).
French public prosecutor Laure Beccuau emphasized that the greater loss is not financial but historical, as the items are irreplaceable cultural artifacts.
The thieves used a truck equipped with a mechanical lift and a battery-powered disc cutter to breach the museum, threatening guards and evacuating them before escaping on scooters.
Security measures have been significantly tightened across France’s cultural institutions in response to the breach.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a daring daylight heist at the Louvre Museum in Paris, four masked thieves stole high-value historical jewellery—including a necklace from Emperor Napoleon and a tiara from Empress Eugenie—within less than eight minutes. The items, valued at €88 million, were taken using a modified truck equipped with a mechanical lift and a battery-powered disc cutter, breaching a glass window in the Galerie d'Apollon. Security flaws, including lack of CCTV and failure of alarms, were exposed, prompting national criticism from President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin. Experts believe the stolen jewels have likely been melted down and smuggled abroad, as the thieves would not have been able to sell them at full value. A damaged crown from Empress Eugenie was found on the escape route, indicating urgency and haste. Authorities are now pursuing a professional team, with only one to two days left before the items may be considered irretrievable.
title: Louvre heist: Stolen jewellery worth €88m, prosecutor says
